GBSeq.GBSeq_definition: Homo sapiens tumor protein p53 (TP53), transcript variant 2, mRNA
GBSeq.GBSeq_taxonomy: Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi; Mammalia; Eutheria; Euarchontoglires; Primates; Haplorrhini; Catarrhini; Hominidae; Homo

GBReference.GBReference_title: Therapeutic Editing of the TP53 Gene: Is CRISPR/Cas9 an Option?
GBReference.GBReference_remark: GeneRIF: Therapeutic Editing of the TP53 Gene: Is CRISPR/Cas9 an Option? Review article; Publication Status: Online-Only

GBReference.GBReference_title: Prognosis, Biology, and Targeting of TP53 Dysregulation in Multiple Myeloma
Common genetic variants in the TP53 pathway and their impact on cancer
GBReference.GBReference_remark: GeneRIF: Common genetic variants in the TP53 pathway and their impact on cancer. Review article

GBReference.GBReference_title: TP53, TP53 Target Genes (DRAM, TIGAR), and Autophagy
Why are there hotspot mutations in the TP53 gene in human cancers?
GBReference.GBReference_remark: GeneRIF: TP53 missense mutant alleles that occur in human cancers are discussed in the context of high resolution models of these p53 mutant protein structures to determine the structural features of mutations (review). Review article

GBReference.GBReference_title: Tumor-Suppressor Functions of the TP53 Pathway
GBReference.GBReference_journal: Cold Spring Harb Perspect Med 6 (5), a026062 (2016)

GBReference.GBReference_title: TP53: an oncogene in disguise
The TP53 gene network in a postgenomic era
GBReference.GBReference_remark: GeneRIF: Recommendations and guidelines for reporting and annotating TP53 variants are also provided, to help researchers generate standardized data that are easy to understand, analyze, and exchange across various cancer variant databases Review article

GBReference.GBReference_title: Does the nonsense-mediated mRNA decay mechanism prevent the synthesis of truncated BRCA1, CHK2, and p53 proteins?
GBReference.GBReference_remark: GeneRIF: the p53 protein encoded by the 770delT allele is as abundant as the wild-type protein, as removal of the C-terminal p53 domain leads to a stabilized mutant protein, whose abundance is markedly increased when NMD is inhibited.

GBReference.GBReference_title: p53 Family isoforms
Expression of p53 and p53/47 are controlled by alternative mechanisms of messenger RNA translation initiation
GBReference.GBReference_remark: GeneRIF: harbouring alternative translation initiation sites, the p53 mRNA gives rise to different levels of the p53 isoforms which help to orchestrate the cell biological outcome of p53 activation

GBReference.GBReference_title: p53/p63/p73 isoforms: an orchestra of isoforms to harmonise cell differentiation and response to stress
p53 isoforms can regulate p53 transcriptional activity
GBReference.GBReference_remark: GeneRIF: p53 isoforms can regulate p53 transcriptional activity.

GBReference.GBReference_title: Regulation of human p53 activity and cell localization by alternative splicing
GBReference.GBReference_remark: GeneRIF: mechanism of p53 regulation originating through alternative splicing of the human p53 gene resulting in the expression of a novel p53 mRNA

GBReference.GBReference_title: The human tumour suppressor gene p53 is alternatively spliced in normal cells
Li-Fraumeni Syndrome
GBReference.GBReference_journal: (in) Adam MP, Feldman J, Mirzaa GM, Pagon RA, Wallace SE and Amemiya A (Eds.); GENEREVIEWS(R); (1993)

GBReference.GBReference_title: Wilms Tumor Predisposition
GBReference.GBReference_journal: (in) Adam MP, Feldman J, Mirzaa GM, Pagon RA, Wallace SE and Amemiya A (Eds.); GENEREVIEWS(R); (1993)

GBReference.GBReference_title: Characterization of the human p53 gene
Localization of gene for human p53 tumour antigen to band 17p13
Transformation associated p53 protein is encoded by a gene on human chromosome 17
Molecular cloning and in vitro expression of a cDNA clone for human cellular tumor antigen p53
Human p53 cellular tumor antigen: cDNA sequence and expression in COS cells
Isolation and characterization of a human p53 cDNA clone: expression of the human p53 gene

GBSeq.GBSeq_comment: REVIEWED REFSEQ: This record has been curated by NCBI staff. The reference sequence was derived from AC087388.9 and AC007421.13.; On Aug 21, 2020 this sequence version replaced NM_001126112.2.; ~Summary: This gene encodes a tumor suppressor protein containing transcriptional activation, DNA binding, and oligomerization domains. The encoded protein responds to diverse cellular stresses to regulate expression of target genes, thereby inducing cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, senescence, DNA repair, or changes in metabolism. Mutations in this gene are associated with a variety of human cancers, including hereditary cancers such as Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Alternative splicing of this gene and the use of alternate promoters result in multiple transcript variants and isoforms. Additional isoforms have also been shown to result from the use of alternate translation initiation codons from identical transcript variants (PMIDs: 12032546, 20937277). [provided by RefSeq, Dec 2016].; ~Publication Note: This RefSeq record includes a subset of the publications that are available for this gene. Please see the Gene record to access additional publications.; ##Evidence-Data-START## ; Transcript exon combination :: AB082923.1, SRR14038194.3914132.1 [ECO:0000332] ; RNAseq introns :: mixed sample support SAMEA1965299, SAMEA1966682 [ECO:0006172] ; ##Evidence-Data-END##; COMPLETENESS: full length.
